summary:
The match between Fiorentina and AS Roma was a tightly contested affair, one that balanced on a knife-edge throughout. Fiorentina emerged victorious with a slender 1-0 win, courtesy of a second-half goal from Milan Badelj. The first half, characterized by a plethora of fouls, interruptions, and sporadic attempts on goal, set the tone for a gritty encounter marked by tactical discipline and defensive resolve.

The game commenced with AS Roma taking the kick-off. Mere seconds into the match, a clearance by Fiorentina was followed by an early foul committed by the home side. AS Roma were awarded an indirect free-kick, which did not translate into an immediate threat. The opening minutes were scrappy, filled with a series of throw-ins and interruptions, disrupting the flow of the game.

At the 10th minute mark, AS Roma demonstrated impressive team play, stringing together a sequence of short passes that showcased their intent to control the game through possession. However, Mohamed Salah's effort to send a dangerous pass into the box was thwarted by Fiorentina's vigilant defense.

The battle in midfield was fierce, as exemplified by Edin Dzeko's foul while contesting for the ball around the 12th minute. Nicola Rizzoli, the referee, was kept busy with multiple stoppages for fouls on both sides, awarding free-kicks that neither team could capitalize on effectively. Josip Ilicic of Fiorentina tried to inject some pace by quickly sending a free-kick into the box around the 13-minute mark, but the delivery was handled well by AS Roma's defense.

The first significant opportunity of the match came in the 15th minute, when Daniele De Rossi located Edin Dzeko with a precise cross. Dzeko's header narrowly missed the left post, a whisker away from giving AS Roma the lead. Moments later, Fiorentina's Carlos Sanchez was shown a yellow card for a flagrant foul, emphasizing the game's physical nature.

The halfway mark of the first half saw Fiorentina enjoy a good spell of possession. While they managed to construct a few promising moves, AS Roma's defense remained steadfast. A notable moment occurred when Iglesias Borja Valero managed to send a pass into the box, but the ensuing chances fizzled out due to solid defensive work from AS Roma.

As the half drew to a close, AS Roma fashioned a few opportunities to break the deadlock. Mohamed Salah received a pass at the edge of the box and unleashed a shot that narrowly sailed over the crossbar, encapsulating the frustration felt by both sides in a half that lacked clear-cut chances.

The second half began with Fiorentina kicking off and immediately setting a more aggressive tone. Within a couple of minutes, Cristian Tello found himself with a chance inside the box, delivering a strong strike that forced a brilliant save from Wojciech Szczesny. Fiorentina continued to pepper AS Roma's goal with attempts, as Josip Ilicic forced another save from Szczesny around the 7-minute mark with a low drive to the middle of the goal.

AS Roma tried to respond but found their efforts either intercepted or easily dealt with by Fiorentina's defense. Fiorentina's Borja Valero remained a constant threat, threading passes into the box, one of which almost allowed Nikola Kalinic to break the deadlock, had Szczesny not been alert.

The game saw its first substitution around the 18th minute as Federico Bernardeschi replaced Cristian Tello for Fiorentina. This substitution injected fresh energy into the home side, translating into an increased tempo. Another substitution for AS Roma saw Stephan El Shaarawy come on for Mohamed Salah.

More fouls marred the flow of the game, with Alessandro Florenzi of AS Roma receiving a yellow card for an aggressive challenge. Nonetheless, AS Roma managed to create a few half-chances, forcing Ciprian Tatarusanu to make a stunning save off a Diego Perotti shot from the edge of the box.

The breakthrough finally came in the 37th minute of the second half. Milan Badelj, having found space, unleashed a decisive snap shot that ricocheted off the left post and nestled into the back of the net, giving Fiorentina the lead. This goal ignited the crowd and put AS Roma on the backfoot, pushing them to chase the game with renewed urgency.

Following the goal, AS Roma attempted to rally. They introduced Francesco Totti, a club legend, in place of Diego Perotti, hoping his experience could turn the tide. Despite this substitution and several efforts to push forward, including a Radja Nainggolan shot that hit the post, AS Roma couldn't find the equalizer.

Fiorentina also made strategic changes, bringing on Sebastian Cristoforo for Nikola Kalinic, aiming to shore up the defense and preserve their slender lead. The final minutes of the match saw frantic efforts by AS Roma, with numerous throw-ins and corners. However, Fiorentina's defense, marshaled by a resolute Tatarusanu, stood firm.

In the dying moments, Alessandro Florenzi and Francesco Totti tried to orchestrate a dramatic finish with attempts from promising positions. Totti, in particular, came close with a strike from the edge of the box that zipped wide of the left post.

After five minutes of added time, the referee blew the final whistle, concluding a hard-fought match that saw Fiorentina edge out AS Roma with a solitary goal. The game, while lacking in clear chances, was a testament to the tactical acumen and defensive organization of both teams. It was a fixture where strategic discipline outweighed individual brilliance, with Milan Badelj’s solitary goal standing out as the decisive moment.

In summary, this game delivered a contest more intriguing for its tactical play than for goal-mouth action. Both Fiorentina and AS Roma exhibited periods of control but lacked the clinical edge in front of goal, save for Badelj’s moment of precision. The victory for Fiorentina, hard-earned and narrow, reflected their persistent probing and ability to exploit the few chances that came their way. Conversely, AS Roma will rue their missed opportunities, particularly Dzeko’s early header and Nainggolan’s shot that struck the post.

The match, ultimately, was a spectacle of strategic football, with the winning goal a product of patience and poise, contrasting sharply with the frenetic attempts of AS Roma to salvage a point in the dying moments. It was a match where every pass and tackle mattered, where defensive solidity and occasional flashes of creativity made the difference on the night.
